title: 112_s3218
content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 is the short title of the act. It aims to improve the coordination of export promotion programs. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to consolidate export promotion activities, clarify roles of Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee members, include State agency representatives, and report on improvements to Export.gov and export control compliance. It also focuses on facilitating export opportunities for small businesses. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 includes provisions for promoting exporting, small business export matchmaking, export control education, inter-agency task force on export financing, and availability of State resource guides on Export.gov. It aims to consolidate export promotion activities and provide information on trade missions and trade fairs. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to enhance export promotion activities by identifying opportunities for consolidation of agencies, coordinating electronic databases, and providing detailed listings of current and future Federal and State-led trade initiatives. The Secretary of Commerce will provide information on Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of departments or agencies in export promotion and financing activities. This includes identifying roles, describing goals and objectives, and measuring and reporting on them. Additionally, the amendment includes involving Congress in these activities. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify roles of departments in export promotion. The amendment includes involving Congress and making recommendations from the Comptroller General on coordination. The United States National Tourism Organization is replaced with the United States Travel Association. SEC. 103 amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. SEC. 104 requires reports to Congress on the activities of the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the chairperson of the TPCC to submit an annual report to Congress by March 30. The report should include details on the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, funding for export promotion activities, and the interagency working groups on energy. Additionally, the inspector general of the Department of Commerce is also required to submit reports to Congress. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce must submit an annual report to Congress by March 30, detailing the TPCC's performance in carrying out its duties and the successful implementation of the strategic plan. The Inspector General should consult with other relevant parties when preparing the report. The TPCC must consult with the inspector general of other Federal departments and agencies. The term 'appropriate congressional committees' includes specific committees from the Senate and House of Representatives. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. Entities specified in this subsection include small business concerns that are exporters, the President's Export Council, State agencies responsible for export promotion or financing, district export councils, and trade associations. SEC. 106. REPORT ON DEVELOPING A SINGLE WINDOW FOR INFORMATION ABOUT EXPORT CONTROL COMPLIANCE. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment, evaluating the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific Senate and House committees. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment, evaluating the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific Senate and House committees. These committees include the Committee on Energy and Commerce and the Committee on Small Business of the House of Representatives. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.

    In this title, the terms ``Administration'' and ``Administrator'' refer to the Small Business Administration and its Administrator, respectively. The term ``region of the Administration'' and ``small business concern'' are defined as per the Small Business Act.

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING.

    Section 22(c)(11) of the Small Business Act is amended to include conducting outreach events in each State promoting exporting as a business opportunity for small businesses. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers. At least one event will be held in each region annually, and events may be coordinated with outreach events. The program authority will end on September 30, 2015. Additionally, there will be export control education under Section 204. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to enhance Federal export finance programs for small businesses. SEC. 206 ensures the availability of State resource guides on export.gov. SEC. 206 mandates the Secretary of Commerce to provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources by State, including relevant agencies and councils.
